title: Matthew Chapter 27 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Matthew chapter 27 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Matthew Chapter 27 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Matthew Chapter 27.

questions.question: Who did the chief priests and elders deliver Jesus to?
questions.correctAnswer: Pontius Pilate
questions.explanation: According to Matthew 27:2, the chief priests and elders delivered Jesus to Pontius Pilate the governor.

questions.question: What did Judas do after he saw that Jesus was condemned?
options: Repented and returned the thirty pieces of silver
questions.correctAnswer: Repented and returned the thirty pieces of silver
questions.explanation: Matthew 27:3 states that Judas repented himself and brought back the thirty pieces of silver to the chief priests and elders.

questions.question: What did Judas say when he returned the silver pieces?
options: I have sinned in that I have betrayed the innocent blood
They forced me to do it
questions.correctAnswer: I have sinned in that I have betrayed the innocent blood
questions.explanation: In Matthew 27:4, Judas said he had sinned by betraying innocent blood.

questions.question: What was the name of the field bought with the thirty pieces of silver?
questions.correctAnswer: The Potter's Field
questions.explanation: Matthew 27:7 explains that the chief priests bought the potter's field with the silver pieces.

questions.question: What title was written over Jesus' head on the cross?
options: THIS IS JESUS THE KING OF THE JEWS
questions.correctAnswer: THIS IS JESUS THE KING OF THE JEWS
questions.explanation: Matthew 27:37 records the inscription above Jesus' head as 'THIS IS JESUS THE KING OF THE JEWS.'

questions.question: Who was the notable prisoner released instead of Jesus?
questions.correctAnswer: Barabbas
questions.explanation: Matthew 27:16 states that Barabbas was the notable prisoner released at the feast.

questions.question: What did Pilate do to show he was innocent of Jesus' blood?
questions.correctAnswer: Washed his hands
questions.explanation: Matthew 27:24 shows Pilate washing his hands before the multitude, declaring himself innocent of Jesus' blood.

questions.question: Who helped Jesus carry his cross?
questions.correctAnswer: Simon of Cyrene
questions.explanation: According to Matthew 27:32, Simon of Cyrene was compelled to bear Jesus' cross.

questions.question: What drink was Jesus offered while on the cross?
questions.correctAnswer: Vinegar mingled with gall
questions.explanation: Matthew 27:34 states that Jesus was given vinegar mingled with gall to drink, which he refused.

questions.question: What happened at the sixth to the ninth hour during Jesus' crucifixion?
options: The veil of the temple was torn
questions.correctAnswer: Darkness covered the land
questions.explanation: Matthew 27:45 records that from the sixth hour to the ninth hour, there was darkness over all the land.

questions.question: True or False: The soldiers placed a crown of thorns on Jesus' head.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Matthew 27:29 describes the soldiers placing a crown of thorns on Jesus' head.

questions.question: True or False: The earth did not shake when Jesus died on the cross.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Matthew 27:51 states that when Jesus died, the earth quaked and rocks were rent.

questions.question: True or False: Joseph of Arimathaea asked Pilate for Jesus' body after his death.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Matthew 27:58 confirms that Joseph of Arimathaea went to Pilate and begged for Jesus' body.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Matthew 27:46: 'Eli, Eli, lama ________?'
questions.correctAnswer: sabachthani
questions.explanation: Matthew 27:46 records Jesus crying out 'Eli, Eli, lama sabachthani?' which means 'My God, my God, why hast thou forsaken me?'

questions.question: What did the chief priests and Pharisees request Pilate to do regarding Jesus' tomb?
options: Make the sepulchre sure until the third day
questions.correctAnswer: Make the sepulchre sure until the third day
questions.explanation: Matthew 27:64 records the chief priests and Pharisees asking Pilate to secure the tomb to prevent the disciples from stealing the body.

medium.title: Matthew Chapter 27 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Matthew Chapter 27 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with guilt over past sins and wonders how to find repentance. Based on Matthew 27, what biblical truth would you share?
options: True repentance involves acknowledging sin and seeking forgiveness, even if it leads to difficult consequences.
Ignoring guilt is the best way to find peace.
Repentance means hiding your mistakes from others.
One should never admit fault to avoid shame.
questions.correctAnswer: True repentance involves acknowledging sin and seeking forgiveness, even if it leads to difficult consequences.
questions.explanation: Judas repented after betraying Jesus by acknowledging his sin (Matthew 27:3-4), showing that true repentance means facing the reality of sin. This teaches us the importance of confession and regret in repentance.

questions.question: How does Matthew 27 instruct us about humility and acceptance in times of suffering?
options: Jesus accepted suffering without defending Himself, showing humility and trust in God's plan.
Jesus fought back against His accusers to prove His innocence.
Suffering should be avoided at all costs through any means.
One should always speak loudly to defend oneself.
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus accepted suffering without defending Himself, showing humility and trust in God's plan.
questions.explanation: Jesus remained silent before Pilate despite accusations (Matthew 27:12-14) and accepted His crucifixion, demonstrating humility and submission to God's will, teaching us to trust God even in trials.

questions.question: A believer is facing peer pressure to act unjustly at work. Based on Matthew 27, what principle about integrity and honesty would you encourage?
options: Maintain integrity even when others act unjustly, as Jesus did in His trial.
Compromise your values to fit in.
Ignore injustice and stay silent always.
Join others in wrongdoing to avoid conflict.
questions.correctAnswer: Maintain integrity even when others act unjustly, as Jesus did in His trial.
questions.explanation: Jesus did not respond to false accusations and remained truthful (Matthew 27:11-14, 23), teaching the importance of integrity and standing firm in truth despite pressure.

questions.question: How does Matthew 27 teach about forgiveness and reconciliation through the actions of Pilate?
options: Pilate washed his hands and declared himself innocent, showing an attempt to avoid responsibility rather than true reconciliation.
Pilate fully forgave Jesus and released Him.
Pilate confessed his sins openly to the crowd.
Pilate denied any involvement in Jesus' fate.
questions.correctAnswer: Pilate washed his hands and declared himself innocent, showing an attempt to avoid responsibility rather than true reconciliation.
questions.explanation: Pilate washed his hands (Matthew 27:24) to symbolize innocence, but he still authorized Jesus' crucifixion, illustrating that true reconciliation requires more than avoiding blame—it requires responsibility and justice.

questions.question: A Christian is struggling with bitterness toward those who wronged them. What does Matthew 27 show about responding to evil with love and humility?
options: Jesus responded to mockery and suffering with silence and forgiveness, teaching us to overcome evil with humility.
It is right to hold grudges against enemies.
One should ignore forgiveness and seek revenge.
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus responded to mockery and suffering with silence and forgiveness, teaching us to overcome evil with humility.
questions.explanation: Jesus endured mockery and abuse without retaliation (Matthew 27:29-31, 39-44), demonstrating humility and forgiveness as a model for believers facing injustice.

questions.question: What does the presence of faithful women ministering to Jesus in Matthew 27 teach about the role of service and fellowship in the church?
options: Serving others with faithfulness and love, even in difficult times, is a vital part of Christian fellowship.
Only men should serve in the church.
Service is optional and unimportant during trials.
Fellowship does not involve practical support.
questions.correctAnswer: Serving others with faithfulness and love, even in difficult times, is a vital part of Christian fellowship.
questions.explanation: The women who followed Jesus and ministered to Him (Matthew 27:55-56) exemplify devoted service and support, encouraging believers to serve others faithfully regardless of circumstances.

questions.question: How does Matthew 27 illustrate the importance of trust in God's plan during trials?
options: Jesus’ submission to crucifixion and His last words show complete trust in God’s purpose despite suffering.
Jesus tried to escape His trial at all costs.
Trusting God means avoiding all hardships.
One should rely only on human strength during trials.
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus’ submission to crucifixion and His last words show complete trust in God’s purpose despite suffering.
questions.explanation: Jesus’ cry, 'My God, my God, why hast thou forsaken me?' (Matthew 27:46) shows deep trust and fulfillment of Scripture, demonstrating that trusting God involves perseverance in suffering.

questions.question: True or False: Matthew 27 shows that even in moments of public humiliation, believers can demonstrate contentment and gratitude by trusting God's sovereignty.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jesus endured mockery and crucifixion (Matthew 27:28-31, 35-36) without complaint, showing contentment and trust in God’s sovereign plan despite humiliation.

questions.question: How does the story of Joseph of Arimathaea in Matthew 27 teach about generosity and stewardship?
options: Joseph generously provided his own tomb for Jesus’ burial, exemplifying sacrificial stewardship.
Generosity is only about giving money, not property.
One should only give when others ask.
questions.correctAnswer: Joseph generously provided his own tomb for Jesus’ burial, exemplifying sacrificial stewardship.
questions.explanation: Joseph’s act of giving his own new tomb (Matthew 27:57-60) demonstrates selfless generosity and stewardship, encouraging believers to give sacrificially for God’s purposes.

questions.question: What biblical virtue is demonstrated by Simon of Cyrene as described in Matthew 27?
options: Willingness to bear burdens and serve others in difficult circumstances.
questions.correctAnswer: Willingness to bear burdens and serve others in difficult circumstances.
questions.explanation: Simon was compelled to carry Jesus’ cross (Matthew 27:32), illustrating the importance of helping others bear their burdens, a key Christian virtue.

questions.question: True or False: According to Matthew 27, the chief priests and Pharisees were concerned that Jesus’ disciples might steal His body to claim He had risen, showing their distrust and fear.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The chief priests and Pharisees requested Pilate to secure the tomb to prevent the disciples from stealing the body (Matthew 27:62-64), revealing their fear of Jesus’ resurrection claims.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: When Pilate saw he could not prevail and a tumult arose, he _______ his hands before the multitude, saying he was innocent of Jesus’ blood.
questions.correctAnswer: washed
questions.explanation: Pilate washed his hands symbolically to show he was not responsible for Jesus’ death (Matthew 27:24), illustrating the importance of personal responsibility.

questions.question: A believer is feeling overwhelmed by trials and wonders how to maintain faith. What does Matthew 27 teach about perseverance through trials?
options: Jesus’ endurance of suffering and death models perseverance and faithfulness even in the darkest moments.
Trials should be avoided at all costs.
Faith can be given up when circumstances are hard.
One should only endure trials if they are easy.
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus’ endurance of suffering and death models perseverance and faithfulness even in the darkest moments.
questions.explanation: Jesus endured crucifixion and death (Matthew 27:35-50), demonstrating steadfast faith and perseverance as an example for believers facing hardships.

questions.question: How does Matthew 27 teach about the importance of prayer and spiritual discipline in facing hardship?
options: Jesus’ fulfillment of prophecy and His composed responses show reliance on Scripture and prayer in hardship.
One should rely only on human wisdom.
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus’ fulfillment of prophecy and His composed responses show reliance on Scripture and prayer in hardship.
questions.explanation: Jesus quoted Scripture on the cross and endured suffering with trust (Matthew 27:9-10, 46), teaching the value of prayer and Scripture in spiritual perseverance.

questions.question: What practical lesson about evangelism and witness can be drawn from the centurion’s confession at Jesus’ death in Matthew 27?
options: God can use even unexpected witnesses to proclaim Jesus as the Son of God.
Evangelism is only for church leaders.
Only Jews can witness about Jesus.
Witnessing is unnecessary after Jesus’ death.
questions.correctAnswer: God can use even unexpected witnesses to proclaim Jesus as the Son of God.
questions.explanation: The Roman centurion acknowledged Jesus as the Son of God (Matthew 27:54), showing that God’s truth can be proclaimed through diverse witnesses, encouraging all believers to share the Gospel.

hard.title: Matthew Chapter 27 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Matthew Chapter 27.

questions.question: What was the significance of the thirty pieces of silver returned by Judas, according to Matthew 27?
options: They were used to buy the potter's field as a burial place for strangers
They were donated to the temple treasury
They were given to the disciples
questions.correctAnswer: They were used to buy the potter's field as a burial place for strangers
questions.explanation: Matthew 27:6-7 explains that the chief priests used the thirty pieces of silver to buy the potter's field to bury strangers, fulfilling prophecy.

questions.question: How does Matthew 27:9-10 demonstrate the theme of prophecy fulfillment in the New Testament?
options: It cites Jeremiah's prophecy regarding the thirty pieces of silver and the potter's field
It references Isaiah’s vision of the suffering servant
It quotes Psalms about the Messiah’s betrayal
It alludes to Ezekiel’s dry bones prophecy
questions.correctAnswer: It cites Jeremiah's prophecy regarding the thirty pieces of silver and the potter's field
questions.explanation: Matthew explicitly connects Judas' betrayal and the purchase of the potter's field to Jeremiah's prophecy, highlighting Jesus as the fulfillment of Old Testament predictions.

questions.question: In Matthew 27:11, how does Jesus respond to Pilate's question about being 'King of the Jews,' and what literary device is used?
options: Jesus answers, 'Thou sayest,' using a Semitic idiom of affirmation
Jesus claims to be a prophet instead
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus answers, 'Thou sayest,' using a Semitic idiom of affirmation
questions.explanation: Jesus’ response is a Semitic expression affirming the statement indirectly, reflecting cultural linguistic context and authorial intent for a Jewish audience.

questions.question: What is the significance of Pilate washing his hands in Matthew 27:24 in the context of ancient Near Eastern legal customs?
options: It symbolized Pilate's attempt to distance himself from responsibility for Jesus' death
It was a ritual purification for entering the temple
It indicated Pilate’s acceptance of guilt
It was a common greeting among Roman officials
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolized Pilate's attempt to distance himself from responsibility for Jesus' death
questions.explanation: Pilate's handwashing is a symbolic act showing his claim of innocence regarding Jesus' crucifixion, reflecting Roman legal culture and political maneuvering.

questions.question: Who was compelled to carry Jesus' cross, and what does this event foreshadow in biblical typology?
options: Simon of Cyrene, foreshadowing the burden-bearing of believers
questions.correctAnswer: Simon of Cyrene, foreshadowing the burden-bearing of believers
questions.explanation: Matthew 27:32 tells that Simon was made to carry the cross, symbolizing the Christian call to take up one’s cross and follow Jesus.

questions.question: What is the theological significance of the temple veil tearing from top to bottom at Jesus' death, as described in Matthew 27:51?
options: It signifies direct access to God for all people, removing the barrier between God and humanity
It marks the temple's physical destruction
It indicates the beginning of a new priesthood
It symbolizes the end of the Sabbath
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies direct access to God for all people, removing the barrier between God and humanity
questions.explanation: The veil tearing symbolizes the removal of separation between God and mankind through Jesus’ sacrifice, fulfilling Old Testament temple symbolism.

questions.question: What Old Testament Psalm is alluded to when Jesus cries out, 'My God, my God, why hast thou forsaken me?' in Matthew 27:46?
questions.correctAnswer: Psalm 22
questions.explanation: Jesus quotes Psalm 22:1, a prophetic psalm describing suffering and eventual vindication, linking his passion to Messianic prophecy.

questions.question: According to Matthew 27:38, who were crucified alongside Jesus, and what might their presence symbolize in the narrative?
options: Two thieves, symbolizing the inclusion of sinners in the salvation story
questions.correctAnswer: Two thieves, symbolizing the inclusion of sinners in the salvation story
questions.explanation: The two thieves crucified with Jesus highlight the theme of redemption extending to sinners, a key theological motif.

questions.question: How does the reaction of the centurion in Matthew 27:54 relate to the theme of revelation to the Gentiles?
options: He declares Jesus as the Son of God, indicating Gentile recognition of Jesus' divine identity
He orders Jesus' body to be taken down immediately
He mocks Jesus along with the crowd
He converts to Judaism on the spot
questions.correctAnswer: He declares Jesus as the Son of God, indicating Gentile recognition of Jesus' divine identity
questions.explanation: The centurion’s confession reveals the expanding recognition of Jesus beyond Jewish circles, emphasizing the universal scope of Jesus’ mission.

questions.question: What was the purpose of the chief priests and Pharisees requesting a guard at the tomb in Matthew 27:62-66?
options: To prevent Jesus' disciples from stealing the body and claiming resurrection
To protect the tomb from grave robbers
questions.correctAnswer: To prevent Jesus' disciples from stealing the body and claiming resurrection
questions.explanation: They feared the disciples would claim Jesus had risen, so they secured the tomb to prevent this, ironically confirming their concern about the resurrection.

questions.question: What is the significance of Jesus being given vinegar mingled with gall in Matthew 27:34, and why did he refuse to drink it?
options: It was a bitter drink used to dull pain, but Jesus refused to avoid numbing his suffering
It was a healing potion, which Jesus rejected
It was a sign of disrespect from the soldiers
It was a ritual drink for prisoners
questions.correctAnswer: It was a bitter drink used to dull pain, but Jesus refused to avoid numbing his suffering
questions.explanation: The gall (a bitter substance) was likely meant to ease suffering, but Jesus’ refusal underscores his willing acceptance of the full agony of crucifixion.

questions.question: How does the mockery of Jesus by the soldiers in Matthew 27:29-30 reflect Old Testament imagery regarding kingship?
options: The crown of thorns and scarlet robe mock the royal crown and purple robe of kings, inverting Jesus' kingship
It symbolizes the coronation of Jesus as king
It is a fulfillment of Davidic covenant
It references the golden calf incident
questions.correctAnswer: The crown of thorns and scarlet robe mock the royal crown and purple robe of kings, inverting Jesus' kingship
questions.explanation: The soldiers’ mockery is a cruel parody of kingly honor, emphasizing the irony of Jesus' true kingship as the suffering Messiah.

questions.question: What literary structure is observed in the sequence of Jesus' trial, scourging, and crucifixion in Matthew 27, and how does it serve the narrative?
options: A chiastic structure highlighting Jesus’ innocence and unjust suffering
A linear chronological account without thematic emphasis
A cyclical pattern reflecting Old Testament festivals
questions.correctAnswer: A chiastic structure highlighting Jesus’ innocence and unjust suffering
questions.explanation: Matthew’s arrangement emphasizes central themes by paralleling events to contrast innocence and wrongful judgment, deepening theological impact.

questions.question: True or False: According to Matthew 27, Jesus answered all accusations made by the chief priests and elders during his trial before Pilate.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Matthew 27:12-14 states that Jesus remained silent when accused by the chief priests and elders, which amazed Pilate.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'His blood be on us, and on our children' in Matthew 27:25 reveal about the crowd's role in Jesus' crucifixion?
options: The crowd accepts collective responsibility for Jesus' death
questions.correctAnswer: The crowd accepts collective responsibility for Jesus' death
questions.explanation: This declaration shows the crowd's willing acceptance of guilt, reflecting the theme of communal culpability in the narrative.

theological.title: Matthew Chapter 27 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Matthew Chapter 27 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Matthew 27, why did Judas return the thirty pieces of silver to the chief priests and elders?
options: He repented because he betrayed innocent blood
He wanted to buy his freedom
He needed to pay a debt
He was ordered to do so by Pilate
questions.correctAnswer: He repented because he betrayed innocent blood
questions.explanation: Matthew 27:3-4 shows that Judas repented and acknowledged his sin of betraying innocent blood. This reflects a recognition of guilt and remorse consistent with biblical teachings on repentance (Psalm 51:4; Ezekiel 33:11; Luke 22:3-4; Acts 1:18).

questions.question: What did the chief priests do with the thirty pieces of silver after Judas cast them into the temple?
options: They bought the potter's field to bury strangers
They returned it to the treasury
They distributed it to the poor
They gave it to Pontius Pilate
questions.correctAnswer: They bought the potter's field to bury strangers
questions.explanation: Matthew 27:6-7 explains that the priests considered the silver as the price of blood and used it to buy a potter's field, fulfilling prophecy (Zechariah 11:12-13; Jeremiah 32:6-9; Matthew 27:9-10; Acts 1:18-19).

questions.question: When Jesus stood before Pilate, how did He respond to the accusation from the chief priests and elders?
options: He remained silent and answered nothing
questions.correctAnswer: He remained silent and answered nothing
questions.explanation: Matthew 27:12-14 records Jesus' silence before the accusations, which amazed Pilate. This fulfills Isaiah 53:7's prophecy of the suffering servant who is silent before his oppressors and demonstrates His submission to God's redemptive plan (Mark 15:5; Luke 23:9; 1 Peter 2:23).

questions.question: Why did Pilate offer to release either Barabbas or Jesus during the feast?
options: Because it was a custom to release a prisoner chosen by the people
To test the loyalty of the chief priests
To avoid responsibility for Jesus' trial
questions.correctAnswer: Because it was a custom to release a prisoner chosen by the people
questions.explanation: Matthew 27:15-17 shows that during the feast, Pilate customarily released a prisoner whom the people wished. This highlights the political and social customs of Roman governance and sets the stage for Jesus' rejection (Luke 23:17; John 18:39; Acts 3:14-15; Isaiah 53:12).

questions.question: What message did Pilate's wife send to him regarding Jesus?
options: To have nothing to do with that just man because she suffered in a dream
To seek a bribe from the chief priests
questions.correctAnswer: To have nothing to do with that just man because she suffered in a dream
questions.explanation: Matthew 27:19 records Pilate's wife's warning based on a troubling dream about Jesus, emphasizing Jesus' innocence and divine significance (Genesis 37:5-11; Daniel 2:1-3; Matthew 1:20; Acts 2:17).

questions.question: How did the crowd respond when Pilate asked whom he should release, Barabbas or Jesus?
options: They asked for Barabbas to be released
They asked for Jesus to be released
They asked for both to be released
questions.correctAnswer: They asked for Barabbas to be released
questions.explanation: Matthew 27:20-21 shows that the chief priests influenced the crowd to request Barabbas' release and demand Jesus' crucifixion, illustrating human rejection of the Messiah despite His innocence (John 18:40; Isaiah 53:3; Romans 5:8; 1 Peter 2:24).

questions.question: What symbolic action did Pilate perform to show he was innocent of Jesus' blood?
options: He washed his hands before the multitude
questions.correctAnswer: He washed his hands before the multitude
questions.explanation: Matthew 27:24 describes Pilate washing his hands as a symbolic gesture of innocence regarding Jesus' death, reflecting a legal and ritual act to dissociate himself from guilt (Exodus 30:17-21; Psalms 26:6; Matthew 23:27; Luke 23:4).

questions.question: What mocking title did the soldiers give Jesus when they put a scarlet robe and crown of thorns on Him?
questions.correctAnswer: King of the Jews
questions.explanation: Matthew 27:28-29 shows the soldiers mocking Jesus by calling Him 'King of the Jews,' a title that ironically affirms His messianic kingship despite their ridicule (John 19:19-22; Zechariah 9:9; Psalm 2:6-7; Revelation 19:16).

questions.question: Who was compelled to carry Jesus' cross on the way to Golgotha?
questions.correctAnswer: Simon of Cyrene
questions.explanation: Matthew 27:32 states that Simon of Cyrene was compelled to bear Jesus' cross, fulfilling the burden-bearing aspect of discipleship and the prophecy of the suffering servant (Isaiah 53:4-5; Mark 15:21; Luke 23:26; John 19:17).

questions.question: What was the place of crucifixion called, and what does the name mean?
questions.correctAnswer: Golgotha, meaning 'place of a skull'
questions.explanation: Matthew 27:33 explains Golgotha as 'the place of a skull,' symbolizing death and judgment, linking to the significance of Christ's atoning sacrifice (John 19:17-18; Hebrews 13:12; Genesis 3:19; Romans 6:23).

questions.question: What did the soldiers do with Jesus' garments during the crucifixion?
options: They parted them and cast lots
questions.correctAnswer: They parted them and cast lots
questions.explanation: Matthew 27:35 records the soldiers dividing Jesus' garments and casting lots, fulfilling Psalm 22:18 and demonstrating the fulfillment of Old Testament prophecy about the Messiah's suffering (John 19:23-24; Psalm 22:1-31; Isaiah 53:12; Luke 23:34).

questions.question: What was written on the inscription placed above Jesus on the cross?
options: THIS IS JESUS THE KING OF THE JEWS
questions.correctAnswer: THIS IS JESUS THE KING OF THE JEWS
questions.explanation: Matthew 27:37 shows the inscription identifying Jesus as 'King of the Jews,' which ironically declares His royal identity and fulfills the messianic expectation (John 19:19-22; Psalm 2:6-9; Revelation 17:14; Luke 23:38).

questions.question: What was the reaction of the centurion and those with him after witnessing the events surrounding Jesus' death?
options: They said, 'Truly this was the Son of God'
They mocked Jesus as a failed king
They fled in fear and confusion
questions.correctAnswer: They said, 'Truly this was the Son of God'
questions.explanation: Matthew 27:54 records the centurion's confession recognizing Jesus' divine identity after the earthquake and supernatural events, affirming Christ's lordship and the power of His death (Mark 15:39; Luke 23:47; John 19:30; Isaiah 53:5).

questions.question: What significant supernatural events accompanied Jesus' death on the cross?
options: The veil of the temple was torn, the earth quaked, and graves opened
A great fire consumed the altar
The sun stopped shining for three days
questions.correctAnswer: The veil of the temple was torn, the earth quaked, and graves opened
questions.explanation: Matthew 27:51-52 describes the veil tearing, earthquake, and resurrection of saints, symbolizing the removal of the barrier between God and humanity and Jesus' victory over death (Hebrews 10:19-22; Exodus 26:31-33; Isaiah 25:7-8; 1 Corinthians 15:54-57).

questions.question: Who requested Jesus' body from Pilate, and what did he do with it?
options: Joseph of Arimathaea, who wrapped it in linen and laid it in a new tomb
Nicodemus, who buried it in a public grave
Peter, who arranged a funeral feast
questions.correctAnswer: Joseph of Arimathaea, who wrapped it in linen and laid it in a new tomb
questions.explanation: Matthew 27:57-60 tells that Joseph, a disciple, asked for Jesus' body, wrapped it, and placed it in a new tomb, fulfilling burial customs and prophecy (Isaiah 53:9; John 19:38-42; Luke 23:50-53; Ezekiel 37:12-14).
